8dfa9d97f5722b79a0f5a9fe79342594.title: How does one approach this task?

35027106315dc8d58d5801706be2d3ae.title: A question regarding this statement: how different should the brand color be from the ui colors?

78c0a212548454c2d659e9d96e76999d.title: This is basically atomic design, no?

d3611d4b762c1b3adc25ca65139b41a1.title: Typically the brand color is part of the UI in some way.

paragraphs.text: Every project starts off with defining a color palette. Brand colors, text colors, UI colors, colors for different types of actions… From that point on, it’s generally not a good idea to use a color that isn’t part of the palette, unless there’s a really, really good reason (which means it should probably go into the palette anyway).
paragraphs.name: 98de
049d
paragraphs.text: Iconography: Dark, light, and tinted variants of our icon set, with slicing set up in a way developers can easily open the Sketch file and grab the assets they need

paragraphs.name: a063
paragraphs.text: Adding some modifiers to the text styles takes this list one step further (color, font weight, text transformations…), but this also either makes the list hard to scan by adding all the different permutations, or will force constant customization to items on the list. (This is an area where I feel Sketch can and will improve over time. A simple alignment overwrite shouldn’t break the connection with the defined text style.)

paragraphs.name: 80da
paragraphs.text: The real breakthrough came when Sketch enabled nesting symbols inside of other symbols. Even as a single designer, there is tremendous value in properly defining, naming, and structuring symbols. Coincidentally, this is how developers structure components as well: starting at the bottom where they define things at a micro level, all the way up to entire screens on a macro level.

Second on the list is typography. Make a list of font sizes needed in the project. The shorter the list, the easier it’ll be to maintain. As with the colors, there generally isn’t any need to deviate from this list.
paragraphs.name: 92e9
a063
paragraphs.text: Adding some modifiers to the text styles takes this list one step further (color, font weight, text transformations…), but this also either makes the list hard to scan by adding all the different permutations, or will force constant customization to items on the list. (This is an area where I feel Sketch can and will improve over time. A simple alignment overwrite shouldn’t break the connection with the defined text style.)

paragraphs.name: 80da
paragraphs.text: The real breakthrough came when Sketch enabled nesting symbols inside of other symbols. Even as a single designer, there is tremendous value in properly defining, naming, and structuring symbols. Coincidentally, this is how developers structure components as well: starting at the bottom where they define things at a micro level, all the way up to entire screens on a macro level.

paragraphs.name: 4f1b
paragraphs.text: Avatars: A set of 8 avatars we use throughout the app. They’re imperfect photos from a diverse set of people.

content.subtitle: The way we design is changing, and so are our tools.
content.metaDescription: Give people a tool, and they’ll find different ways to put it to use. No two designers work the same way, but I’m predicting that will change over the next couple of years.

bd47a31a3af7.title: You’ll need headers, subheaders, actions, base copy, sub copy… Try to figure out the font sizes and…

paragraphs.name: d170
paragraphs.text: You’ll need headers, subheaders, actions, base copy, sub copy… Try to figure out the font sizes and line heights you’ll need for all these elements before you dive in. Once you’ve defined them, stick to them (or change them across the entire design).
